qas.question: What was King Juan Carlos' response to the media when asked if he would sign a bill supporting same-sex marriage?

answers.text: "Soy el Rey de España y no el de Bélgica"

qas.question: What other controversial bill did the king give his assent to in 2010?

answers.text: a law permitting abortion on demand

qas.question: When did same-sex marriages become legal in Spain?

context: No provision within the constitution grants the monarch an ability to veto legislation directly; however, no provision prohibits the sovereign from withholding royal assent, which effectively constitutes a veto. When the Spanish media asked King Juan Carlos if he would endorse the bill legalising same-sex marriages, he answered <a0_0>"Soy el Rey de España y no el de Bélgica"<a0_0/> ("I am the King of Spain and not that of Belgium")—a reference to King Baudouin I of Belgium, who had refused to sign the Belgian law legalising abortion. The King gave royal assent to Law 13/2005 on 1 July 2005; the law was gazetted in the Boletín Oficial del Estado on 2 July and came into effect on <a2_0>3 July 2005<a2_0/>. Likewise, in 2010, King Juan Carlos gave royal assent to <a1_0>a law permitting abortion on demand<a1_0/>.
